titles.title: Aoki Hagane no Arpeggio: Ars Nova
蒼き鋼のアルペジオ -アルス・ノヴァ-
蒼き鋼のアルペジオ -ARS NOVA-
Arpeggio of Blue Steel
Arpeggio of Blue Steel
푸른 강철의 아르페지오
苍蓝钢铁战舰

recommendations.recommendation: Animation and production design are very nice indeed. The story`s premise is a good one, too. So it is a shame how the characters (shallow humans, absurd mental models) and redundant talk, used to blow up a 8-episodes-storyline to 12 episodes, pretty much ruin it.
reminds me of Sekirei..lots of beautiful girls/battleships but with an awesome plot and war battles..one of my fav this season
there is a new concept in this anime. don`t let the rating fool you it worth watching it.
The show was very enjoyable overall in my opinion. Quite enjoyable character progression and plot. The last episode felt a bit rushed but everything else was good.

I really enjoyed this anime. CGI was actually to my liking. I think it gave a smooth, consistent performance throughout the series. Characters were likeable. Story was kept to the minimum and i think it was the right decision. A little journey with simple yet meaningful drama, little bit of comedy and fan service here and there, and, of-course, lots of action and explosion to keep things lively! If you can go past the premise of moe battleship girls, stop trying to find reason for every detail or looking for flaws and enjoy it as a whole you will find this a well put together show. 7.5/10

Really good. The Fog are an interesting foe, and the girls as ships genre is a lot of fun. The plot is good, as are the characters. Although there`s some some seemingly random fan service thrown in, it`s still definitely worth a watch.

I cant express how much I really enjoyed this series, totally devastated that is all come to an end, it just started to feel like the whole story was picking up as well. at least now i can focus on the manga! Ignore the ratings.
I don`t know what`s wrong with the rating.... but this one it`s one of the best anime of fall season!!! Battle scenes are incredible!

Be warned, the anime turns out to be a lot different from the manga, that is the main reason for the low rating: haters gonna hate. Nevertheless, the show is very good taken on its own, it`s much more than a pew pew anime, and some things are handled even better than in the manga (inho). Don`t be fooled by the usual "know it all" bad review guy, don`t pass on this one.
Unusual CG animation, but its easy to get used to it, plus its really a nice one. Dont let the rating fool you, this anime is a must see one. One of the best in this season.
Great anime! The plot is nice and has enough good surprises. The character development is on level. Most people will certainly love it.

A different approach, but a definite breath of fresh air. The animation is different from what you normally would be accustomed to, but you can easily get used to it. The story is well told, the characters grow, and the fights are just awesome. Like everyone says, don`t listen to the ratings and watch for yourself. This is the definite underdog this season, and is given much too few credit than what it deserves.
somewhat fan service-y, but the plot is very interesting. The characters are also creative. An underdog series.

This show in terms of Characterization and art have taken many risks but the execution was superb! I greatly enjoyed this series over the time I watched the simulcast and I will re-watch it again. It really was a pleasure aboard this show and with it`s crew! However one think irks me about this show... It`s for never saying "You sunk my battleship"

anime.description: A fleet of unmanned ships, called the Fleet of Fog, equipped with super advanced weapons and technology suddenly appeared all over the world. Mankind didn`t have the capability to face such a fleet and so was defeated in a devastating naval war. This resulted in mankind being driven out of the seas and losing their ability to travel the seas. Years after this devastating naval war, http://anidb.net/ch56439 [Chihaya Gunzou] and his friends are aboard the http://anidb.net/ch59269 [I-401], a former Fleet of Fog submarine. Together with the I-401`s mental model, http://anidb.net/ch56440 [Iona], they take on the Fleet of Fog.

tag.name: meta tags
tag.description: These tags are used for maintenance.

tag.name: seinen
tag.description: Seinen, literally "young man", is one of the main demographic classifications applied to manga, and, by extension, to anime, especially manga-based ones. As the name implies, seinen works are marketed primarily to an audience of young men; the age range commonly understood to be the target of such works goes roughly from 17 to somewhere in the 40s.

tag.name: stuffed toy
tag.description: A stuffed toy is a toy sewn from cloth, plush, or other textiles, and stuffed with straw, beans, plastic pellets, cotton, synthetic fibres, or other similar materials. Stuffed toys are also known as plush toys (U.S. English) from plush, the outer material used, and soft toys or cuddly toys (British English). Stuffed toys are made in many different forms, often resembling animals, legendary creatures, cartoon characters or inanimate objects. They are often used as comfort objects, for display or collecting and given as gifts, such as for graduation, Valentine`s Day or birthdays.

tag.name: prodigy
tag.description: Character is very good at everything he/she does.

tag.name: target audience
tag.description: Anime, like everything else in the modern world, is targeted towards specific audiences, both implicitly by the creators and overtly by the marketing. While categories are associated with specific sex and age groups, this is not a bar on the anime being enjoyed by people who don`t fit into that band; not only do crossover titles exist, but the categories also have a considerable following outside their main demographic, and a person might as well enjoy anime from all categories. Still, does not invalidate the usefulness of marking a title as one of the categories; the same themes will likely be treated differently in anime geared for different audiences. Only one should not jump the gun and assume that a title will be more or less serious or present content in this or that way due to its target audience, or conversely assume the target audience on the content and its presentation alone. As such, the audience categories help form a broad impression of how a title might work with the announced themes, but offer little to no in-depth information about specific content or its treatment. The audience categories originate from manga magazines, which group titles of a same intended audience into a magazine that is advertised as belonging to that category, and so manga-based anime will have the category from their parent work. As for anime based on other works, the audience is often debatable, but comparing information such as time slot to the manga-based anime generally helps figure out the most likely possibility.

tag.name: themes
tag.description: Themes describe the very central elements important to the anime stories. They set the backdrop against which the protagonists must face their challenges. Be it School Life, present Daily Life, Military action, Cyberpunk, Law and Order detective work, Sports, or the Underworld. These are only but a few of the more typical backgrounds for anime plots. Add to that a Conspiracy setting with a possible tragic outcome, the Themes span most of the imaginable subject matter relevant to anime.

tag.name: original work
tag.description: What the anime is based on! Mostly of academic interest, but a useful bit of info, hinting at the possible depth of story.

tag.name: setting
tag.description: The setting describes in what time and place an anime takes place. To a certain extent it describes what you can expect from the world in the anime.

tag.name: elements
tag.description: Next to Themes setting the backdrop for the protagonists in anime, there are the more detailed plot Elements that centre on character interactions: "What do characters do to each other or what is done to them?". Is it violent Action, an awe-inspiring Adventure in a foreign place, the gripping life of a Detective, a slapstick Comedy, an Ecchi Harem anime, a SciFi epic, or some Fantasy travelling adventure?

tag.name: place
tag.description: The places the anime can take place in. Includes more specific places such as a country on Earth, as well as more general places such as a dystopia or a mirror world.

tag.name: Earth
tag.description: The Earth is the third planet from the Sun, and the densest and fifth-largest of the eight planets in the Solar System. It is in effect a ball of hot mud, but on the surface it`s cold enough, so most of us live on it (or are supposed to). It is circa 4.5 billion years old, and, unless we humans succeed in destroying it over the next couple of centuries, it is expected to last for quite another while, though the changes in the Sun`s emissions due to its aging will likely cause the extinction of everything; the species of earthlings are guaranteed to die, even if we fail to kill them -- unless, of course, we find ourselves another planet and figure out a way to take everything there. Our little planet on a corner of this galaxy may mean nothing in the grand scheme of things, but to its inhabitants it is their home, so, as a species, we cherish it dearly, to the point many cultures even to this day deify it. Being the home to the human civilizations, the Earth is the main setting of most fiction, be it anime or otherwise, but not only are many titles set in other places, such as unrelated fantasy worlds, in a considerable number of fictional titles the Earth is actually destroyed by aggressive alien invaders.

tag.name: human enhancement
tag.description: The enhancement of humans can take various forms: It can be something comparatively non-intrusive as a power-up drug, a form of machine implantation or cyberization ("SAC Solid State Society"), or outright - possibly atrocious - genetic manipulation ("Ao no 6-gou"). Plot-wise enhanced protagonists in anime usually have to pay a price for their enhancements, be it physical or mental.

tag.name: Japan
tag.description: Last stronghold for humanity. If Tokyo falls, it`s all over. Tokyo Tower will undoubtedly fall anyway.

tag.name: manga
tag.description: Manga is the lifeblood that drives the anime industry. Everything and its mother is based on manga. However! There are exceptions where the manga was not the basis for the anime. It`s common practice to make manga adaptations of many popular anime, there`s a manga based on Evangelion, and two (one shounen and one shoujo) based on each of Escaflowne and Mahou Tsukai Tai. Also it`s quite common to release manga and anime versions of a story in parallel, for instance Nadesico and Shoujo Kakumei Utena. There are also cases where an anime continues in a manga, as in the case of Angel Beats! and Angel Beats: Heaven`s Door, or reverse.

tag.name: Asia
tag.description: Asia is the world`s largest and most populous continent.

tag.name: action
tag.description: Action anime usually involve a fairly straightforward story of good guys versus bad guys, where most disputes are resolved by using physical force. It often contains a lot of shooting, explosions and fighting.

tag.name: science fiction
tag.description: Science fiction stories usually focus on how situations could be different in the future when we are more technologically advanced; due to either our own achievements or having met with other civilizations whom we have learned from.

tag.name: adventure
tag.description: Adventures are exciting stories, with new experiences or exotic locales. Adventures are designed to provide an action-filled, energetic experience for the viewer. Rather than the predominant emphasis on violence and fighting that is found in pure action anime, however, the viewer of adventures can live vicariously through the travels, conquests, explorations, creation of empires, struggles and situations that confront the main characters, actual historical figures or protagonists. Under the category of adventures, we can include traditional swashbucklers, serialized films, and historical spectacles, searches or expeditions for lost continents, "jungle" and "desert" epics, treasure hunts and quests, disaster films, and heroic journeys or searches for the unknown. Adventure films are often, but not always, set in an historical period, and may include adapted stories of historical or literary adventure heroes, kings, battles, rebellion, or piracy.

tag.name: romance
tag.description: Romance describes a story that deals with love between two or more characters typically also having an optimistic ending. Romance is also a difficulty encountered when creating a harem.

tag.name: friendship
tag.description: The feeling of trust, kindness, and friendship between a group of high school students for example, is a central theme of this anime.

tag.name: disaster
tag.description: A disaster is a large-scale natural or human-made situation that causes great loss of or threat to life, health, property, or environment in such a way that society or environment are affected substantially.

tag.name: conspiracy
tag.description: The conspiracy thriller (or paranoid thriller) is a sub-genre of the thriller which flourished in the 1970s in the US (and was echoed in other parts of the world) in the wake of a number of high-profile scandals and controversies (most notably Vietnam, the assassination of President Kennedy, Chappaquiddick and Watergate), and which exposed what many people regarded as the clandestine machinations and conspiracies beneath the orderly fabric of political life. The protagonists of conspiracy thrillers are often journalists or amateur investigators who find themselves (often inadvertently) pulling on a small thread which unravels a vast conspiracy that ultimately goes "all the way to the top".

tag.name: nano machines
tag.description: The anime features sub-microscopic (nano = 10E-9 = one billionth) machines, associated with many almost "magical" abilities. E.g. machines that float in the bloodstream, repairing human cells in situ.

tag.name: genetic modification
tag.description: Story-wise, genetic modification is usually centred on humans, probably the most subtle and creepy way of messing with mankind. Playing with the fear of the unknown, genetically altered humans are technically a new species, that may not only surpass but actually replace unaltered humans. The level of modification will vary from subtle changes in "look" (e.g. super-human beauty), to mental enhancements (PSI powers), to more or less atrocious adaptations to extreme environments (breath under water, radiation resistance). Note that changes in Aliens would be difficult to pinpoint, after all they are alien.

tag.name: war
tag.description: War is a phenomenon of organized violent conflict, typified by extreme aggression, societal disruption and adaptation, and high mortality. The objective of warfare differs in accord with a group`s role in a conflict: The goals of offensive warfare are typically the submission, assimilation or destruction of another group, while the goals of defensive warfare are simply the repulsion of the offensive force and, often, survival itself. Relative to each other, combatants in warfare are called enemies. The terms military, militant, and militarism each refer to fundamental aspects of war, i.e. the organized group, the combative individual, and the supportive ethos (respectively). Source: wiki

tag.name: strategy
tag.description: Instead of blindly running into a battle or trap, at least one of the protagonists devises a clever strategy to significantly improve the odds of victory.

tag.name: cel-shaded animation
tag.description: Cel shading (often misspelled as `cell shading`) or toon shading is a type of non-photorealistic rendering designed to make 3-D computer graphics appear to be flat. Cel-shading is often used to mimic the style of a comic book or cartoon. It is somewhat recent, appearing from around the beginning of the twenty-first century. The name comes from cels (short for celluloid), the clear sheets of acetate which are painted on for use in traditional 2D animation.

tag.name: all-female enemy crew
tag.description: For some reason the enemy crew is solely comprised of an all-female cast.

tag.name: CGI
tag.description: Computer animation is the art of creating moving images via the use of computers. It is a subfield of computer graphics and animation. Increasingly it is created by means of 3D computer graphics, though 2D computer graphics are still widely used for stylistic, low bandwidth, and faster real-time rendering needs. Sometimes the target of the animation is the computer itself, but sometimes the target is another medium, such as film. It is also referred to as CGI (Computer-generated imagery or computer-generated imaging), especially when used in films.

tag.name: sudden loli companion appearance
tag.description: The main character meets a preadolescent girl in an unexpected way becoming a friend / partner of the main character. (The term loli is short for Lolita meaning a girl in preadolescent age. Typical attributes are moe, cute, and innocent.)

tag.name: OP and ED sung by characters
tag.description: OP and/or ED in this anime is sung by the characters and animation shows them singing.

tag.name: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
tag.description: The title of Philip K. Dick`s SF novel (movie: Blade Runner). The phrase implies a set of existential questions: Do artificial beings (e.g. Replicants, Bioroids, or other AI constructs) dream, feel, or have a soul? If memories can be implanted, what makes real memories real? By contrast — what makes humans human? What is reality? These are central themes e.g. in all of the Ghost in the Shell and Appleseed series / movies.

tag.name: journey of evolution
tag.description: When the characters make a journey or some kind of test that either shows them how they have evolved or make them evolve to a new self, not quite uncommon to a stronger self.

tag.name: the power of love
tag.description: The power of love is not only the strongest power known to mankind, it is the strongest power in the universe. The power of love conquers all things. It makes people cry, it makes people laugh, it can make them sing and occasionally it even brings dead people back to life, just so. More so than the power of friendship, the power of true love gives boundless strength and resolution; by the power of love every hardship can be overcome, every issue can be resolved and it does make people resistant to food poisoning (caused by the bad cooking of their loved ones). Even the big bad evil doesn`t stand a chance against the power of true love and often ends up redeemed. Even when the power of love is not literally and directly responsible, the scene is often set so that the audience is left with the impression that it was "really responsible".

tag.name: 3D CG animation
tag.description: Abbreviation for "three-dimensional computer generated animation" or "computer graphics" (CGI). The traditional 2D art is enhanced by 3D imagery developed through computer modeling software. Done in the right way, this union of 3D in a 2D animated world can be a very beautiful relationship. The difference lies in what lacks the traditional 2D animation all together and may give term to something produced entirely with 3D graphics (such as the 2006 remake of "Appleseed" , 2007`s "Vexille", the 2008 addition to the "Biohazard" series and the more well known "Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within" and "Advent Children").

tag.name: TO BE MOVED TO CHARACTER
tag.description: Tags under this parent tag are going to be moved to character tags and removed from the anime they`re currently assigned to. They will be blocked from the anime system once that move is complete. Please help with that job if you know what characters they should be assigned to.

tag.name: technical aspects
tag.description: It may sometimes be useful to know about technical aspects of a show, such as information about its broadcasting or censorship. Such information can be found here.

tag.name: character related tags which need deleting or merging

character.name: Chihaya Gunzou
character.description: The captain of the submarine I-401. He had attended the National Maritime Institute of Technology, a school established to preserve and pass on maritime technology and culture, before meeting Iona. He and 4 other students leave aboard the I-401, making them fugitives from the Japanese government.

character.name: Iona
character.description: I-401`s mental model. Why she`s allying with the humans is a mystery.

character.name: Takao
character.description: The Mental Model of the Takao-class heavy cruiser Takao.

character.name: Kongou
character.description: The Mental Model of the Kongou-class battlecruiser Kongou. She commands the 1st Oriental Fleet that patrols the waters around Japan.

character.name: Maya
character.description: The Mental Model of the Takao-class heavy cruiser Maya.

character.name: Fleet of Fog
character.description: A mysterious fleet of unmanned sentient warships that appeared and defeated mankind`s navies and drove mankind from the seas. The ships comprising the Fleet of Fog all share appearances and names of ships from World War II, though are armed with weapons and technology far exceeding anything humans have yet developed. To be able to better understand humans they have begun using female-shaped embodiments of consciousness called "Mental Models" to allow them to perceive the world more like a human.

character.name: Blue Steel
character.description: An organization lead by Chihaya Gunzou and currently composed of his crew and the I-401.

character.name: Haruna
character.description: The Mental Model of the Kongou-class battlecruiser Haruna.

character.name: Kirishima
character.description: The Mental Model of the Kongou-class battlecruiser Kirishima.
